natural problem:
A polynomial \[
P(x)=c_{2004}x^{2004}+ c_{2003}x^{2003}+ \cdots+ c_{1}x+ c_{0}
\]has real coefficients with $c_{2004} \neq 0$ and 2004 distinct complex zeros $z_{k}=a_{k}+ b_{k}i$, $1 \leq k \leq 2004$ with $a_k$ and $b_k$ real, $a_1 = b_1 = 0$, and \[
\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_{k}= \sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_{k}.
\]Which of the following quantities can be a nonzero number?

A. $c_0$

B. $c_{2003}$

C. $b_{2}b_{3} \dotsm b_{2004}$

D. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_{k}$

E. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}c_{k}$
natural solution: Since $z_1 = 0$, it follows that $c_0 = P(0) = 0$. The nonreal zeros of $P$ must occur in conjugate pairs, so $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0$ and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_k = 0$ also. The coefficient $c_{2003}$ is the sum of the zeros of $P$, which is \[

\sum_{k=1}^{2004}z_k = \sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_k + i\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0. \]Finally, since the degree of $P$ is even, at least one of $z_2, \ldots, z_{2004}$ must be real, so at least one of $b_2, \ldots, b_{2004}$ is 0 and consequently $b_2 b_3 \dotsm b_{2004}=0$.

Thus the quantities in $\textbf{(A)}$, $\textbf{(B)}$, $\textbf{(C)}$, and $\textbf{(D)}$ must all be 0. Note that the polynomial \[ P(x) = x(x-2)(x-3)\cdots(x-2003)\displaystyle\left(x + \sum_{k=2}^{2003} k\displaystyle\right)
\]satisfies the given conditions, and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} c_k = P(1) \ne 0$. That means our answer is $\boxed{\text{E}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and c :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and b :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>x. (\<Sum>k \<in> {0..2004}. c k * x ^ k))"
and h1 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> k \<in> {1..2004}. P (z k) = 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> k \<in> {1..2004}. z k = Complex (a k) (b k)"
and h4 : "a 1 = 0"
and h5 : "b 1 = 0"
and h6 : "sum a {1..2004} = sum b {1..2004}"
shows  "\<exists> k \<in> {1..2004}. c k \<noteq> 0"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A polynomial \[
P(x)=c_{2004}x^{2004}+ c_{2003}x^{2003}+ \cdots+ c_{1}x+ c_{0}
\]has real coefficients with $c_{2004} \neq 0$ and 2004 distinct complex zeros $z_{k}=a_{k}+ b_{k}i$, $1 \leq k \leq 2004$ with $a_k$ and $b_k$ real, $a_1 = b_1 = 0$, and \[
\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_{k}= \sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_{k}.
\]Which of the following quantities can be a nonzero number?

A. $c_0$

B. $c_{2003}$

C. $b_{2}b_{3} \dotsm b_{2004}$

D. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_{k}$

E. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}c_{k}$ The final Answer is \text{E}
 ### Proof
 Since $z_1 = 0$, it follows that $c_0 = P(0) = 0$. The nonreal zeros of $P$ must occur in conjugate pairs, so $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0$ and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_k = 0$ also. The coefficient $c_{2003}$ is the sum of the zeros of $P$, which is \[
 \sum_{k=1}^{2004}z_k = \sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_k + i\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0. \]Finally, since the degree of $P$ is even, at least one of $z_2, \ldots, z_{2004}$ must be real, so at least one of $b_2, \ldots, b_{2004}$ is 0 and consequently $b_2 b_3 \dotsm b_{2004}=0$.
 Thus the quantities in $\textbf{(A)}$, $\textbf{(B)}$, $\textbf{(C)}$, and $\textbf{(D)}$ must all be 0. Note that the polynomial \[ P(x) = x(x-2)(x-3)\cdots(x-2003)\displaystyle\left(x + \sum_{k=2}^{2003} k\displaystyle\right)
 \]satisfies the given conditions, and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} c_k = P(1) \ne 0$. That means our answer is $\boxed{\text{E}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and c :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex" and a :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and b :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>x. (\<Sum>k \<in> {0..2004}. c k * x ^ k))"
and h1 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> k \<in> {1..2004}. P (z k) = 0"
and h3 : "\<forall> k \<in> {1..2004}. z k = Complex (a k) (b k)"
and h4 : "a 1 = 0"
and h5 : "b 1 = 0"
and h6 : "sum a {1..2004} = sum b {1..2004}"
shows  "\<exists> k \<in> {1..2004}. c k \<noteq> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Suppose $P$ is a complex polynomial of degree 2004 with leading coefficient not equal to zero and roots $z_1, z_2, ..., z_{2004}$, where each $z_k$ is a complex number with real part $a_k$ and imaginary part $b_k$. If $a_1 = b_1 = 0$ and the sum of the real parts equals the sum of the imaginary parts, prove that there exists at least one non-zero coefficient in the polynomial $P$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and a b c :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (\<Sum> i \<le> 2004. c i * (x powr i))"
and h1 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> k \<in> {1..2004}. (\<exists> ak bk. a k = ak \<and> b k = bk \<and> P (Complex ak bk) = 0)"
and h3 : "a 1 = 0"
and h4 : "b 1 = 0"
and h5 : "(\<Sum> k \<le> 2004. a k) = (\<Sum> k \<le> 2004. b k)"
shows  "\<exists> k \<in> {0..2004}. c k \<noteq> 0"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A polynomial \[
P(x)=c_{2004}x^{2004}+ c_{2003}x^{2003}+ \cdots+ c_{1}x+ c_{0}
\]has real coefficients with $c_{2004} \neq 0$ and 2004 distinct complex zeros $z_{k}=a_{k}+ b_{k}i$, $1 \leq k \leq 2004$ with $a_k$ and $b_k$ real, $a_1 = b_1 = 0$, and \[
\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_{k}= \sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_{k}.
\]Which of the following quantities can be a nonzero number?

A. $c_0$

B. $c_{2003}$

C. $b_{2}b_{3} \dotsm b_{2004}$

D. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_{k}$

E. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}c_{k}$ The final Answer is \text{E}
 ### Proof
 Since $z_1 = 0$, it follows that $c_0 = P(0) = 0$. The nonreal zeros of $P$ must occur in conjugate pairs, so $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0$ and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_k = 0$ also. The coefficient $c_{2003}$ is the sum of the zeros of $P$, which is \[
 \sum_{k=1}^{2004}z_k = \sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_k + i\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0. \]Finally, since the degree of $P$ is even, at least one of $z_2, \ldots, z_{2004}$ must be real, so at least one of $b_2, \ldots, b_{2004}$ is 0 and consequently $b_2 b_3 \dotsm b_{2004}=0$.
 Thus the quantities in $\textbf{(A)}$, $\textbf{(B)}$, $\textbf{(C)}$, and $\textbf{(D)}$ must all be 0. Note that the polynomial \[ P(x) = x(x-2)(x-3)\cdots(x-2003)\displaystyle\left(x + \sum_{k=2}^{2003} k\displaystyle\right)
 \]satisfies the given conditions, and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} c_k = P(1) \ne 0$. That means our answer is $\boxed{\text{E}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and a b c :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = (\<Sum> i \<le> 2004. c i * (x powr i))"
and h1 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> k \<in> {1..2004}. (\<exists> ak bk. a k = ak \<and> b k = bk \<and> P (Complex ak bk) = 0)"
and h3 : "a 1 = 0"
and h4 : "b 1 = 0"
and h5 : "(\<Sum> k \<le> 2004. a k) = (\<Sum> k \<le> 2004. b k)"
shows  "\<exists> k \<in> {0..2004}. c k \<noteq> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem:
Consider a complex polynomial $P(x)$ of degree 2004 given by $P(x) = \sum_{i=0}^{2004} c_i * x^i$, where $c_{2004} \neq 0$. 

Suppose that for each natural number $k$ in the range 1 to 2004, there exist real numbers $a_k$ and $b_k$ such that $a_k = a(k)$, $b_k = b(k)$ and $P(a_k + b_k * i) = 0$, where $i$ is the imaginary unit.

Also, it is given that $a(1) = b(1) = 0$ and the sum of all $a_k$ is equal to the sum of all $b_k$ for $k$ ranging from 1 to 2004.

Under these conditions, show that there exists a natural number $k$ in the range 0 to 2004 such that $c_k \neq 0$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes c :: "int \<Rightarrow> real" and z :: "int \<Rightarrow> complex" and a b :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 2004 \<longrightarrow> (z k = Complex (a k) (b k))"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 2004 \<longrightarrow> (a k = b k)"
and h3 : "a 1 = 0"
and h4 : "b 1 = 0"
and h5 : "c 0 = 0"
and h6 : "c 2003 = 0"
and h7 : "(\<Prod> k=2..2004. b k) = 0"
and h8 : "(\<Sum> k=1..2004. a k) = 0"
shows  "(\<Sum> k=1..2004. c k) \<noteq> 0"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A polynomial \[
P(x)=c_{2004}x^{2004}+ c_{2003}x^{2003}+ \cdots+ c_{1}x+ c_{0}
\]has real coefficients with $c_{2004} \neq 0$ and 2004 distinct complex zeros $z_{k}=a_{k}+ b_{k}i$, $1 \leq k \leq 2004$ with $a_k$ and $b_k$ real, $a_1 = b_1 = 0$, and \[
\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_{k}= \sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_{k}.
\]Which of the following quantities can be a nonzero number?

A. $c_0$

B. $c_{2003}$

C. $b_{2}b_{3} \dotsm b_{2004}$

D. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_{k}$

E. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}c_{k}$ The final Answer is \text{E}
 ### Proof
 Since $z_1 = 0$, it follows that $c_0 = P(0) = 0$. The nonreal zeros of $P$ must occur in conjugate pairs, so $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0$ and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_k = 0$ also. The coefficient $c_{2003}$ is the sum of the zeros of $P$, which is \[
 \sum_{k=1}^{2004}z_k = \sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_k + i\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0. \]Finally, since the degree of $P$ is even, at least one of $z_2, \ldots, z_{2004}$ must be real, so at least one of $b_2, \ldots, b_{2004}$ is 0 and consequently $b_2 b_3 \dotsm b_{2004}=0$.
 Thus the quantities in $\textbf{(A)}$, $\textbf{(B)}$, $\textbf{(C)}$, and $\textbf{(D)}$ must all be 0. Note that the polynomial \[ P(x) = x(x-2)(x-3)\cdots(x-2003)\displaystyle\left(x + \sum_{k=2}^{2003} k\displaystyle\right)
 \]satisfies the given conditions, and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} c_k = P(1) \ne 0$. That means our answer is $\boxed{\text{E}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes c :: "int \<Rightarrow> real" and z :: "int \<Rightarrow> complex" and a b :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 2004 \<longrightarrow> (z k = Complex (a k) (b k))"
and h2 : "\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 2004 \<longrightarrow> (a k = b k)"
and h3 : "a 1 = 0"
and h4 : "b 1 = 0"
and h5 : "c 0 = 0"
and h6 : "c 2003 = 0"
and h7 : "(\<Prod> k=2..2004. b k) = 0"
and h8 : "(\<Sum> k=1..2004. a k) = 0"
shows  "(\<Sum> k=1..2004. c k) \<noteq> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem:
Consider a function $c$ mapping integers to real numbers, and a function $z$ mapping integers to complex numbers. Suppose that $c(2004) \neq 0$.

Let $a$ and $b$ be functions mapping integers to real numbers, and suppose that for each integer $k$ from 1 to 2004 (inclusive), $z(k)$ equals the complex number formed by $a(k)$ and $b(k)$, and $a(k) = b(k)$.

Also, suppose that $a(1) = 0$, $b(1) = 0$, $c(0) = 0$, $c(2003) = 0$, the product of all $b(k)$ for $k$ from 2 to 2004 equals zero, and the sum of all $a(k)$ for $k$ from 1 to 2004 equals zero.

Prove that the sum of all $c(k)$ for $k$ from 1 to 2004 is not zero.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes c a b :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" 
and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" 
and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>x. (\<Sum>i\<le>2004. c i * x ^ i))"
and h1 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>k \<le> 2004. z k = Complex (a k) (b k)"
and h3 : "a 1 = 0 \<and> b 1 = 0"
and h4 : "(\<Sum>k\<le>2004. a k) = (\<Sum>k\<le>2004. b k)"
and h5 : "\<forall>k \<le> 2004. P (Re (z k)) = 0 \<and> P (Im (z k)) = 0"
shows  "c 0 \<noteq> 0 \<or> c 2003 \<noteq> 0 \<or> (\<Prod>k=2..2004. b k) \<noteq> 0 \<or> (\<Sum>k\<le>2004. a k) \<noteq> 0 \<or> (\<Sum>k\<le>2004. c k) \<noteq> 0"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A polynomial \[
P(x)=c_{2004}x^{2004}+ c_{2003}x^{2003}+ \cdots+ c_{1}x+ c_{0}
\]has real coefficients with $c_{2004} \neq 0$ and 2004 distinct complex zeros $z_{k}=a_{k}+ b_{k}i$, $1 \leq k \leq 2004$ with $a_k$ and $b_k$ real, $a_1 = b_1 = 0$, and \[
\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_{k}= \sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_{k}.
\]Which of the following quantities can be a nonzero number?

A. $c_0$

B. $c_{2003}$

C. $b_{2}b_{3} \dotsm b_{2004}$

D. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_{k}$

E. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}c_{k}$ The final Answer is \text{E}
 ### Proof
 Since $z_1 = 0$, it follows that $c_0 = P(0) = 0$. The nonreal zeros of $P$ must occur in conjugate pairs, so $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0$ and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_k = 0$ also. The coefficient $c_{2003}$ is the sum of the zeros of $P$, which is \[
 \sum_{k=1}^{2004}z_k = \sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_k + i\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0. \]Finally, since the degree of $P$ is even, at least one of $z_2, \ldots, z_{2004}$ must be real, so at least one of $b_2, \ldots, b_{2004}$ is 0 and consequently $b_2 b_3 \dotsm b_{2004}=0$.
 Thus the quantities in $\textbf{(A)}$, $\textbf{(B)}$, $\textbf{(C)}$, and $\textbf{(D)}$ must all be 0. Note that the polynomial \[ P(x) = x(x-2)(x-3)\cdots(x-2003)\displaystyle\left(x + \sum_{k=2}^{2003} k\displaystyle\right)
 \]satisfies the given conditions, and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} c_k = P(1) \ne 0$. That means our answer is $\boxed{\text{E}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes c a b :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" 
and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" 
and z :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>x. (\<Sum>i\<le>2004. c i * x ^ i))"
and h1 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>k \<le> 2004. z k = Complex (a k) (b k)"
and h3 : "a 1 = 0 \<and> b 1 = 0"
and h4 : "(\<Sum>k\<le>2004. a k) = (\<Sum>k\<le>2004. b k)"
and h5 : "\<forall>k \<le> 2004. P (Re (z k)) = 0 \<and> P (Im (z k)) = 0"
shows  "c 0 \<noteq> 0 \<or> c 2003 \<noteq> 0 \<or> (\<Prod>k=2..2004. b k) \<noteq> 0 \<or> (\<Sum>k\<le>2004. a k) \<noteq> 0 \<or> (\<Sum>k\<le>2004. c k) \<noteq> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
Let $P(x)$ be a polynomial of degree 2004, where $P(x)=\sum_{i=0}^{2004} c_i x^i$ and $c_{2004} \neq 0$.

Let $z(k)$ be a complex number for each natural number $k \leq 2004$ such that $z(k)=a_k + b_k*i$, where $i$ is the imaginary unit, $a_1 = 0$, $b_1 = 0$, and the sum of all $a_k$ equals the sum of all $b_k$.

Suppose that for all $k \leq 2004$, $P$ evaluated at the real and imaginary parts of $z(k)$ is zero.

Show that at least one of the following is true: $c_0 \neq 0$, $c_{2003} \neq 0$, the product of all $b_k$ for $2 \leq k \leq 2004$ is not zero, the sum of all $a_k$ is not zero, or the sum of all $c_k$ is not zero.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes c :: "int \<Rightarrow> real" and z :: "int \<Rightarrow> complex" and a b :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h1 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 2004 \<longrightarrow> z k = Complex (a k) (b k) \<and> z k \<noteq> z (k + 1)"
and h2 : "a 1 = 0"
and h3 : "b 1 = 0"
and h4 : "sum a {1..2004} = sum b {1..2004}"
shows  "sum c {1..2004} \<noteq> 0"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A polynomial \[
P(x)=c_{2004}x^{2004}+ c_{2003}x^{2003}+ \cdots+ c_{1}x+ c_{0}
\]has real coefficients with $c_{2004} \neq 0$ and 2004 distinct complex zeros $z_{k}=a_{k}+ b_{k}i$, $1 \leq k \leq 2004$ with $a_k$ and $b_k$ real, $a_1 = b_1 = 0$, and \[
\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_{k}= \sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_{k}.
\]Which of the following quantities can be a nonzero number?

A. $c_0$

B. $c_{2003}$

C. $b_{2}b_{3} \dotsm b_{2004}$

D. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_{k}$

E. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}c_{k}$ The final Answer is \text{E}
 ### Proof
 Since $z_1 = 0$, it follows that $c_0 = P(0) = 0$. The nonreal zeros of $P$ must occur in conjugate pairs, so $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0$ and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_k = 0$ also. The coefficient $c_{2003}$ is the sum of the zeros of $P$, which is \[
 \sum_{k=1}^{2004}z_k = \sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_k + i\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0. \]Finally, since the degree of $P$ is even, at least one of $z_2, \ldots, z_{2004}$ must be real, so at least one of $b_2, \ldots, b_{2004}$ is 0 and consequently $b_2 b_3 \dotsm b_{2004}=0$.
 Thus the quantities in $\textbf{(A)}$, $\textbf{(B)}$, $\textbf{(C)}$, and $\textbf{(D)}$ must all be 0. Note that the polynomial \[ P(x) = x(x-2)(x-3)\cdots(x-2003)\displaystyle\left(x + \sum_{k=2}^{2003} k\displaystyle\right)
 \]satisfies the given conditions, and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} c_k = P(1) \ne 0$. That means our answer is $\boxed{\text{E}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes c :: "int \<Rightarrow> real" and z :: "int \<Rightarrow> complex" and a b :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h1 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 2004 \<longrightarrow> z k = Complex (a k) (b k) \<and> z k \<noteq> z (k + 1)"
and h2 : "a 1 = 0"
and h3 : "b 1 = 0"
and h4 : "sum a {1..2004} = sum b {1..2004}"
shows  "sum c {1..2004} \<noteq> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem:
Consider functions $a$, $b$, $c$ mapping integers to real numbers, and function $z$ mapping integers to complex numbers, with the following properties:

1. $c(2004) \neq 0$.
2. For every integer $k$ such that $1 \leq k \leq 2004$, $z(k) = a(k) + b(k)i$, and $z(k) \neq z(k+1)$.
3. $a(1) = 0$ and $b(1) = 0$.
4. The sum of $a(k)$ from $k=1$ to $2004$ is equal to the sum of $b(k)$ from $k=1$ to $2004$.

The problem is to show that the sum of $c(k)$ from $k=1$ to $2004$ is not equal to zero.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes c a b :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and i :: nat
assumes h0 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h1 : "(\<forall>k \<in> {1..2004}. a k \<in> Reals \<and> b k \<in> Reals)"
and h2 : "a 1 = 0"
and h3 : "b 1 = 0"
and h4 : "sum a {1..2004} = sum b {1..2004}"
and h5 : "(\<forall>k \<in> {1..2004}. \<exists>z. z = Complex (a k) (b k))"
shows  "sum c {1..2004} \<noteq> 0"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A polynomial \[
P(x)=c_{2004}x^{2004}+ c_{2003}x^{2003}+ \cdots+ c_{1}x+ c_{0}
\]has real coefficients with $c_{2004} \neq 0$ and 2004 distinct complex zeros $z_{k}=a_{k}+ b_{k}i$, $1 \leq k \leq 2004$ with $a_k$ and $b_k$ real, $a_1 = b_1 = 0$, and \[
\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_{k}= \sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_{k}.
\]Which of the following quantities can be a nonzero number?

A. $c_0$

B. $c_{2003}$

C. $b_{2}b_{3} \dotsm b_{2004}$

D. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_{k}$

E. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}c_{k}$ The final Answer is \text{E}
 ### Proof
 Since $z_1 = 0$, it follows that $c_0 = P(0) = 0$. The nonreal zeros of $P$ must occur in conjugate pairs, so $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0$ and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_k = 0$ also. The coefficient $c_{2003}$ is the sum of the zeros of $P$, which is \[
 \sum_{k=1}^{2004}z_k = \sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_k + i\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0. \]Finally, since the degree of $P$ is even, at least one of $z_2, \ldots, z_{2004}$ must be real, so at least one of $b_2, \ldots, b_{2004}$ is 0 and consequently $b_2 b_3 \dotsm b_{2004}=0$.
 Thus the quantities in $\textbf{(A)}$, $\textbf{(B)}$, $\textbf{(C)}$, and $\textbf{(D)}$ must all be 0. Note that the polynomial \[ P(x) = x(x-2)(x-3)\cdots(x-2003)\displaystyle\left(x + \sum_{k=2}^{2003} k\displaystyle\right)
 \]satisfies the given conditions, and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} c_k = P(1) \ne 0$. That means our answer is $\boxed{\text{E}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes c a b :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and i :: nat
assumes h0 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h1 : "(\<forall>k \<in> {1..2004}. a k \<in> Reals \<and> b k \<in> Reals)"
and h2 : "a 1 = 0"
and h3 : "b 1 = 0"
and h4 : "sum a {1..2004} = sum b {1..2004}"
and h5 : "(\<forall>k \<in> {1..2004}. \<exists>z. z = Complex (a k) (b k))"
shows  "sum c {1..2004} \<noteq> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a set of 2004 real numbers, where each pair of numbers forms a complex number with the real part from set a and the imaginary part from set b. The first element in both sets is 0. The sum of all elements in set a is equal to the sum of all elements in set b. Show that the sum of the corresponding complex numbers (set c) is not zero.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and c a b :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>x. \<Sum>k\<le>2004. c k * x powr k)"
and h1 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>k\<le>2004. P (a k + \<i> * b k) = 0"
and h3 : "\<forall>k\<le>2004. a k \<in> Reals \<and> b k \<in> Reals"
and h4 : "a 1 = 0"
and h5 : "b 1 = 0"
and h6 : "(\<Sum>k\<le>2004. a k) = (\<Sum>k\<le>2004. b k)"
shows  "(\<Sum>k\<le>2004. c k) \<noteq> 0"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A polynomial \[
P(x)=c_{2004}x^{2004}+ c_{2003}x^{2003}+ \cdots+ c_{1}x+ c_{0}
\]has real coefficients with $c_{2004} \neq 0$ and 2004 distinct complex zeros $z_{k}=a_{k}+ b_{k}i$, $1 \leq k \leq 2004$ with $a_k$ and $b_k$ real, $a_1 = b_1 = 0$, and \[
\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_{k}= \sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_{k}.
\]Which of the following quantities can be a nonzero number?

A. $c_0$

B. $c_{2003}$

C. $b_{2}b_{3} \dotsm b_{2004}$

D. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_{k}$

E. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}c_{k}$ The final Answer is \text{E}
 ### Proof
 Since $z_1 = 0$, it follows that $c_0 = P(0) = 0$. The nonreal zeros of $P$ must occur in conjugate pairs, so $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0$ and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_k = 0$ also. The coefficient $c_{2003}$ is the sum of the zeros of $P$, which is \[
 \sum_{k=1}^{2004}z_k = \sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_k + i\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0. \]Finally, since the degree of $P$ is even, at least one of $z_2, \ldots, z_{2004}$ must be real, so at least one of $b_2, \ldots, b_{2004}$ is 0 and consequently $b_2 b_3 \dotsm b_{2004}=0$.
 Thus the quantities in $\textbf{(A)}$, $\textbf{(B)}$, $\textbf{(C)}$, and $\textbf{(D)}$ must all be 0. Note that the polynomial \[ P(x) = x(x-2)(x-3)\cdots(x-2003)\displaystyle\left(x + \sum_{k=2}^{2003} k\displaystyle\right)
 \]satisfies the given conditions, and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} c_k = P(1) \ne 0$. That means our answer is $\boxed{\text{E}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and c a b :: "nat \<Rightarrow> complex"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>x. \<Sum>k\<le>2004. c k * x powr k)"
and h1 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>k\<le>2004. P (a k + \<i> * b k) = 0"
and h3 : "\<forall>k\<le>2004. a k \<in> Reals \<and> b k \<in> Reals"
and h4 : "a 1 = 0"
and h5 : "b 1 = 0"
and h6 : "(\<Sum>k\<le>2004. a k) = (\<Sum>k\<le>2004. b k)"
shows  "(\<Sum>k\<le>2004. c k) \<noteq> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem:
Consider a polynomial $P(x)$ of degree 2004 with complex coefficients, given by $P(x) = \sum_{k=0}^{2004} c_k x^k$, where the coefficient $c_{2004}$ is not zero. 

Suppose that for every natural number $k$ up to 2004, $P(a_k + i b_k) = 0$, where $a_k$ and $b_k$ are real numbers, and $a_1 = b_1 = 0$. Also, the sum of all $a_k$'s is equal to the sum of all $b_k$'s.

Prove that the sum of all coefficients of $P(x)$ is not zero.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and a b c :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda> x. (\<Sum>k\<le>2004. c k * x ^ k))"
and h1 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> k \<le> 2004. \<exists> z. P z = 0 \<and> z = Complex (a k) (b k)"
and h3 : "a 1 = 0"
and h4 : "b 1 = 0"
and h5 : "(\<Sum>k\<le>2004. a k) = (\<Sum>k\<le>2004. b k)"
shows  "(\<Sum>k\<le>2004. c k) \<noteq> 0"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A polynomial \[
P(x)=c_{2004}x^{2004}+ c_{2003}x^{2003}+ \cdots+ c_{1}x+ c_{0}
\]has real coefficients with $c_{2004} \neq 0$ and 2004 distinct complex zeros $z_{k}=a_{k}+ b_{k}i$, $1 \leq k \leq 2004$ with $a_k$ and $b_k$ real, $a_1 = b_1 = 0$, and \[
\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_{k}= \sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_{k}.
\]Which of the following quantities can be a nonzero number?

A. $c_0$

B. $c_{2003}$

C. $b_{2}b_{3} \dotsm b_{2004}$

D. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_{k}$

E. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}c_{k}$ The final Answer is \text{E}
 ### Proof
 Since $z_1 = 0$, it follows that $c_0 = P(0) = 0$. The nonreal zeros of $P$ must occur in conjugate pairs, so $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0$ and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_k = 0$ also. The coefficient $c_{2003}$ is the sum of the zeros of $P$, which is \[
 \sum_{k=1}^{2004}z_k = \sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_k + i\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0. \]Finally, since the degree of $P$ is even, at least one of $z_2, \ldots, z_{2004}$ must be real, so at least one of $b_2, \ldots, b_{2004}$ is 0 and consequently $b_2 b_3 \dotsm b_{2004}=0$.
 Thus the quantities in $\textbf{(A)}$, $\textbf{(B)}$, $\textbf{(C)}$, and $\textbf{(D)}$ must all be 0. Note that the polynomial \[ P(x) = x(x-2)(x-3)\cdots(x-2003)\displaystyle\left(x + \sum_{k=2}^{2003} k\displaystyle\right)
 \]satisfies the given conditions, and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} c_k = P(1) \ne 0$. That means our answer is $\boxed{\text{E}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and a b c :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda> x. (\<Sum>k\<le>2004. c k * x ^ k))"
and h1 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> k \<le> 2004. \<exists> z. P z = 0 \<and> z = Complex (a k) (b k)"
and h3 : "a 1 = 0"
and h4 : "b 1 = 0"
and h5 : "(\<Sum>k\<le>2004. a k) = (\<Sum>k\<le>2004. b k)"
shows  "(\<Sum>k\<le>2004. c k) \<noteq> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem:
Consider a complex polynomial function P(x) that is defined by the series sum of c(k) * x^k for all k up to 2004, where c(2004) is not zero. 

For all k up to 2004, there exists a complex number z (with real part a(k) and imaginary part b(k)) such that P(z) equals zero. 

The real and imaginary parts of the first complex root (when k=1) are both zero. 

The sum of all the real parts (a(k)) is equal to the sum of all the imaginary parts (b(k)) for all k up to 2004. 

Prove that the sum of all the coefficients c(k) for all k up to 2004 is not zero.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> k \<in> {1..2004}. P (Complex (a k) (b k)) = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> k \<in> {2..2004}. a k = b k"
and h3 : "a 1 = b 1 = 0"
shows  "\<exists>k \<in> {1..2004}. c k \<noteq> 0"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A polynomial \[
P(x)=c_{2004}x^{2004}+ c_{2003}x^{2003}+ \cdots+ c_{1}x+ c_{0}
\]has real coefficients with $c_{2004} \neq 0$ and 2004 distinct complex zeros $z_{k}=a_{k}+ b_{k}i$, $1 \leq k \leq 2004$ with $a_k$ and $b_k$ real, $a_1 = b_1 = 0$, and \[
\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_{k}= \sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_{k}.
\]Which of the following quantities can be a nonzero number?

A. $c_0$

B. $c_{2003}$

C. $b_{2}b_{3} \dotsm b_{2004}$

D. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_{k}$

E. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}c_{k}$ The final Answer is \text{E}
 ### Proof
 Since $z_1 = 0$, it follows that $c_0 = P(0) = 0$. The nonreal zeros of $P$ must occur in conjugate pairs, so $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0$ and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_k = 0$ also. The coefficient $c_{2003}$ is the sum of the zeros of $P$, which is \[
 \sum_{k=1}^{2004}z_k = \sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_k + i\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0. \]Finally, since the degree of $P$ is even, at least one of $z_2, \ldots, z_{2004}$ must be real, so at least one of $b_2, \ldots, b_{2004}$ is 0 and consequently $b_2 b_3 \dotsm b_{2004}=0$.
 Thus the quantities in $\textbf{(A)}$, $\textbf{(B)}$, $\textbf{(C)}$, and $\textbf{(D)}$ must all be 0. Note that the polynomial \[ P(x) = x(x-2)(x-3)\cdots(x-2003)\displaystyle\left(x + \sum_{k=2}^{2003} k\displaystyle\right)
 \]satisfies the given conditions, and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} c_k = P(1) \ne 0$. That means our answer is $\boxed{\text{E}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real" and P :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h1 : "\<forall> k \<in> {1..2004}. P (Complex (a k) (b k)) = 0"
and h2 : "\<forall> k \<in> {2..2004}. a k = b k"
and h3 : "a 1 = b 1 = 0"
shows  "\<exists>k \<in> {1..2004}. c k \<noteq> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Assume that $a(k)$, $b(k)$, and $c(k)$ are real-valued functions on the set of natural numbers. Further assume that $c(2004) \neq 0$, that for all $k$ in the range from 1 to 2004, the complex number $a(k) + b(k)i$ is a root of the polynomial $P$, that for all $k$ in the range from 2 to 2004, $a(k) = b(k)$, and that $a(1) = b(1) = 0$. Show that there exists a $k$ in the range from 1 to 2004 such that $c(k) \neq 0$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and c :: "int \<Rightarrow> real" and z :: "int \<Rightarrow> complex" and a b :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. P x = (\<Sum>i=2004 downto 0. (c i) * x powr i)"
and h1 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 2004 \<longrightarrow> z k = a k + \<i> * b k"
and h3 : "a 1 = b 1 = 0"
and h4 : "(\<Sum>k=1..2004. a k) = (\<Sum>k=1..2004. b k)"
shows  "\<exists>k. 0 < k \<and> k \<le> 2004 \<and> c k \<noteq> 0"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A polynomial \[
P(x)=c_{2004}x^{2004}+ c_{2003}x^{2003}+ \cdots+ c_{1}x+ c_{0}
\]has real coefficients with $c_{2004} \neq 0$ and 2004 distinct complex zeros $z_{k}=a_{k}+ b_{k}i$, $1 \leq k \leq 2004$ with $a_k$ and $b_k$ real, $a_1 = b_1 = 0$, and \[
\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_{k}= \sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_{k}.
\]Which of the following quantities can be a nonzero number?

A. $c_0$

B. $c_{2003}$

C. $b_{2}b_{3} \dotsm b_{2004}$

D. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_{k}$

E. $\sum_{k=1}^{2004}c_{k}$ The final Answer is \text{E}
 ### Proof
 Since $z_1 = 0$, it follows that $c_0 = P(0) = 0$. The nonreal zeros of $P$ must occur in conjugate pairs, so $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0$ and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} a_k = 0$ also. The coefficient $c_{2003}$ is the sum of the zeros of $P$, which is \[
 \sum_{k=1}^{2004}z_k = \sum_{k=1}^{2004}a_k + i\sum_{k=1}^{2004} b_k = 0. \]Finally, since the degree of $P$ is even, at least one of $z_2, \ldots, z_{2004}$ must be real, so at least one of $b_2, \ldots, b_{2004}$ is 0 and consequently $b_2 b_3 \dotsm b_{2004}=0$.
 Thus the quantities in $\textbf{(A)}$, $\textbf{(B)}$, $\textbf{(C)}$, and $\textbf{(D)}$ must all be 0. Note that the polynomial \[ P(x) = x(x-2)(x-3)\cdots(x-2003)\displaystyle\left(x + \sum_{k=2}^{2003} k\displaystyle\right)
 \]satisfies the given conditions, and $\sum_{k=1}^{2004} c_k = P(1) \ne 0$. That means our answer is $\boxed{\text{E}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "complex \<Rightarrow> complex" and c :: "int \<Rightarrow> real" and z :: "int \<Rightarrow> complex" and a b :: "int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. P x = (\<Sum>i=2004 downto 0. (c i) * x powr i)"
and h1 : "c 2004 \<noteq> 0"
and h2 : "\<forall>k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> 2004 \<longrightarrow> z k = a k + \<i> * b k"
and h3 : "a 1 = b 1 = 0"
and h4 : "(\<Sum>k=1..2004. a k) = (\<Sum>k=1..2004. b k)"
shows  "\<exists>k. 0 < k \<and> k \<le> 2004 \<and> c k \<noteq> 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: The polynomial $P(x)$ is defined as $P(x) = \sum_{i=2004}^{0} c_i x^i$, where $c_i$ are real coefficients and $c_{2004} \neq 0$. Also, for each $k$ in the range $1 \leq k \leq 2004$, $z_k$ is defined as $a_k + ib_k$, where $a_k$ and $b_k$ are real numbers and $a_1 = b_1 = 0$. Furthermore, the sum of all $a_k$ equals the sum of all $b_k$ for $k$ in the range $1 \leq k \leq 2004$. Prove that there exists an $k$ in the range $0 < k \leq 2004$ such that $c_k \neq 0$.
